author: Ann Binlot
title: UBS Partners With Annie Leibovitz On Global Exhibition Tour
text: Fifteen years ago Annie Leibovitz embarked on a book of portraits titled Women made in collaboration with her late partner, writer Susan Sontag. Although Sontag passed away in 2004, Leibovitz continued expanding the series. UBS announced today that it has partnered with the photographer for a global tour of the series, which features new portraits “ reflective of the changes in the roles of women today.”The exhibition tour will be free to the public and will launch in London this January and will continue to 10 cities around the globe, including Tokyo, San Francisco, Hong Kong, Singapore, Mexico City, Istanbul, Frankfurt, New York and Zurich.[caption id="attachment_1226" align="" width="650"] Annie Leibovitz, New York City, 2004 © Annie Leibovitz[/caption]The new photographs will become part of the UBS Art Collection, one of the most important corporate collections of contemporary art comprised of more than 35,000 works by artists like Cindy Sherman, Tina Barney and Sam Taylor Wood. The partnership also marks UBS’s continued support of the arts “Aligned with the focus UBS placeson education,learning programs will accompany the exhibition presented in partnership with cultural organizations around the world,” reads a release. “These initiatives will explore ways of seeing through photography, working with young people in local communities.” "We are delighted to announce this special partnership with Annie Leibovitz," said Johan Jervøe, Global Group chief marketing officer of UBS. " Throughout her career Annie, has captured the pulse and tenor of contemporary life, creating unique, personal and insightful portraits that have become her trademark. This exhibition will celebrate women effecting positive change. We want to enable as many people as possible to see and respond to this thought-provoking series and to be inspired to fulfil their own creative practice." Leibovitz’s most famous photographs include the famous 1980 Rolling Stone cover of John Lennon curled up nude next to Yoko Ono, and the 1991 Vanity Fair cover of a very pregnant and naked Demi Moore.
